medium: Two-sided color lithograph and etching with punched-out and collaged dots on five strips of buff Japanese paper
creditline: Gift of James Kraft, Class of 1957
inscribed:
Numbered in graphite, lower left: 9//30

Signed and dated in graphite, recto, lower right: Howardena Pindell 1980

makers.displaydate: born 1943, Philadelphia, PA; active New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: Howardena Doreen Pindell, born 1943, Philadelphia, PA; active New York, NY

makers.prefix: Printed by Judith Solodkin and Patricia Branstead at
makers.displaymaker: Printed by Judith Solodkin and Patricia Branstead at Aeropress

texts.textentryhtml: Beginning in the 1960s, Pindell developed a highly refined and craft-driven formal aesthetic while maintaining a commitment to political activism. She exposed racism in the art world in written reports and in the scathing video Free, White, and 21—produced in 1980, the same year as this print, which incorporates the hole-punching procedure of her layered painted collages. The confetti-like surface pulsates with tiny vectors and sequences of numbers, which had personal significance to the artist, whose father was a mathematician. Together with the title, Kyoto, the delicate rice papers evoke Pindell’s first trip to Japan, in 1979. The red dots may allude to a childhood memory of a root beer stand where she and her father were given mugs with red circles on the bottom—a means of designating utensils for use by African Americans.
texts.remarks: Hold: A Meditation on Black Aesthetics

texts.textentryhtml:
In the 1960s, Pindell developed a craft‑inspired aesthetic that maintained her commitment to political activism. The confetti-like surface of this print pulsates with tiny elements depicting vectors and sequences of numbers that had personal significance to Pindell, whose father was a
mathematician. Together with the work’s title, the artist’s use of delicate strips of rice paper recalls her first trip to Japan in 1979. The red dots may allude to a memory of a childhood road trip, when at a root beer stand in northern Kentucky, she and her father were given mugs with red circles on the bottom—a means of designating separate utensils for African Americans. These myriad references to the artist’s life reflect
Pindell’s weaving of her identity into her artistic practice, even when making nearly abstract works.
